summary: Dumbledore’s train when he dies brings him to an alternate universe with Tom Riddle asking for the defense post. There, he rights his wrongs and hires Tom Riddle as a Defense Professor to keep him from becoming Voldemort. It works. (Mostly.) Canon!Harry does the same unintentionally when he is a Firm Adult and stumbles into this AU Hogwarts hoping to teach defense. He cannot bc Tom. There is only teaching one spot available: Muggle Studies. Chaos ensues as Muggle Studies becomes everyone’s favorite class and gains a reputation as the most difficult course at Hogwarts. Tom Riddle is enraged, concerned, and… turned on?

text:
There’s something distinctly cult-like to all the muggle studies students. They cluck their tongues at students who don’t take the elective and call them “poor things.” Every single student taking muggle studies has a tell-tell harried look about them, a fanatical gleam in their eyes, and superiority clinging to the fabric of their clothes. 
Muggle-borns not taking the class often protest assertions from students that, “Muggle Studies is easily the hardest class at Hogwarts!”
A sixth-year muggle-born, Tawny Dingle says, “It can’t be if you already know about muggles! I mean what do you learn, what electricity is?”
Her sixth-year friend, a Hufflepuff who Tom Riddle never learned the name of, asserts, “Not just what it is, but how it works! We’re terribly behind you see, we were supposed to have learned about circuits ages ago and we can only take two days for science so we’ll never catch up. Harry’s just teaching us the very basics about Eddison, Tesla, and Alternating Current because what we really ought to be learning is Biology. Do you know why we need to breathe?”
Tom’s nose crinkles in distaste. Muggle-Studies is NOT supposed to garner this kind of fervor. He needs to know what is happening inside that classroom. Harry Potter, the new professor with wild black hair and emerald eyes somehow managed to get muggle studies into a two-hour daily class with optional evening sections and students keep showing up and Tom’s had eight of his Slytherin students beg him to get them into the class. And Potter lets students call him Harry and he wears distressed jeans, v-neck cable-knit sweaters, and combat boots and is easily cool. Which is NOT what Muggle-Studies professors are supposed to be. It is an affront to Tom who unto the arrival of Harry Potter was the favourite professor. 
Tom needs to be able to get into one of Harry’s classes. For Observation. Of Course.
Dingle blinks, wide-eyed, “Why do we need to breathe? I know that. I mean yeah, to live.”
 
“But why does breathing help us live?” The Hufflepuff pushes.
 
“Oxygen?”'
 
“And what does Oxygen do?”
 
Dingle bows her head, “I don’t know.”
 
The Hufflepuff adjusts her robes with the air of someone self-satisfied. “Of course you don’t. You’re not taking Muggle-Studies. But to put you out of your miserable ignorance, it’s because during aerobic cellular respiration, the glucose you store from food reacts in a chain ending with oxygen which produces Adenosine Triphosphate which is used as energy for all your living processes.” 
Tom Riddle frowns. He thinks of himself as being rather brilliant and he understands almost nothing from what the young Hufflepuff just said. 
A Slytherin hears the exchange and says, “Well, I heard Potter’s a squib.”
A third-year who clearly has also taken Muggle-Studies stands up and shouts, “And what if he is?”
This interests Tom greatly and for the next week, he spends all his time observing Harry Potter. The professor seems to own six different sweaters and three pairs of pants. Whenever it’s foggy, the man will head to the kitchen and grab a slab of bleeding, juicy meat, thank crying houselves, and disappear to somewhere around the Quidditch pitch.
Harry never uses magic. Not for grading papers (which he does with a pen on a notebook!), not for heating his tea, not for cleaning himself off. He may indeed be a squib. Disappointing and surprising. Tom cannot recruit him for later purposes. Yet… Tom cannot help but be impressed by how the man has managed to become so important to Hogwarts despite lacking magic. 
Harry Potter catches Tom following him one evening on his way to a class and flashes a bright smile. 
“Ah! Tom, would you like to sit it in my class today?”
Tom initially begins a polite refusal, “I’d have to refu–,” but looking into Harry’s (when did he become Harry?) sparkling eyes and remembering his desire to learn what exactly goes on in the muggle studies classes, he says, “Actually, yes. That would be excellent.” 
Harry falls into step with Tom and they walk side-by-side to the muggle-studies classroom. The interior is filled with potted plants and wooden tables with sofas around them and a large blackboard. 
Harry settles himself comfortably sitting atop a desk at the front of the room. He pats the space beside and Tom sits down on the indicated spot stiffly. Harry’s thighs are firm yet soft and he smells nice – like lemon with a hint of sandalwood. 
Tom’s face feels warm for reasons he cannot quite discern. 
“You’re here for my favorite class,” Harry says, voice warm and soft and sweet. Heat pools in the bottom of Tom’s belly as Harry’s breath ghosts over his ears. “IB Economics with the seventh years.”
The students filter in, all bright-eyed and bushy-tailed which they SHOULD NOT BE for an after-dinner optional course. They should be dead behind their eyes and drooping onto their desks. (Merlin knows sometimes kids fall asleep even in Tom's exciting Dark Arts lessons, and yet not a single child in Harry's class looks even remotely tired. Something is off here, something is very very wrong.) Harry peels off his sweater, revealing a tight grey shirt beneath. 
For no reason at all, Tom wants to shrink Harry’s discarded sweater down and put it in his pocket.
Harry stands and Tom gets an excellent view of a well-muscled slim back and round bottom. Not that he is noticing such things. 
“The defense professor is joining us today in order to learn what we do, and I expect you all on your best behaviour. Where we last left our heroes we were discussing money theory, now can anyone tell me the money multiplier?”
 
“One over the reserve ratio!” The class choruses. 
 
“And what is the problem with banks in the Wizarding World?”
 
“They do not have a reserve ratio,” one student says. 
 
Harry nods encouragingly. “Someone else, expand on that.”
 
Another student says, “They don’t have one because they don’t actually lend money out. They just keep gold in vaults.”
 
“Good, Avery,” Harry praises. Tom wants to lock up the word “Good,” from Harry’s lips and keep it forever. “One could say that Gringotts isn’t a bank so much as a storage facility. Keep going, class. Look at your notes if you must.”
 
“Ah!” A Gryffindor student yells out, one of the Blacks. “It keeps the wizarding world stagnant. There’s no way for the money supply to increase so growth is almost impossible and it makes resources perpetually scarce.”
 
Tom feels his head start to spin.
 
“Thank you for that wonderful reading of your notes, Sirius. Precisely. Which is why you all will change that. We’re going to bring a true financial system to this country and we’re going to do it together. We’re going to create growth. But we only have eight months until you sit for your IB exams and we are already much too behind. Today we will be reviewing the impact of taxes on GDP and if you are very good, we may be able to begin on inflation next week. Tomorrow, we change the world.”
 
There is a collective cheer from the class. Harry begins to speak and write things on the board and Tom sits on the desk entirely convinced that Harry has managed to start a cult. As a squib no less! It is all rather concerning, but Harry makes so many compelling points Tom begins to think that Harry may be on to something.
 
For no reason at all, Tom sits next to Harry at the high table for meals for the next few weeks. The division between those taking Muggle-Studies and those not continues to grow. And then, three months into the term, a Patronus in the shape of a Phoenix delivers a message to Harry, “Fawkes would like to see you,” intones Dumbledore’s voice.
 
Harry releases a deep sigh and says, “Expecto Patronum,” and a brilliant stag bursts forth from his wand. 
 
NOT A SQUIB! Tom’s mind immediately supplies. POWERFUL WIZARD WHO IS HOT AND SMART, it also supplies. 
 
“Yeah, yeah, I’ll be there,” Harry says in a put-upon tone.
 
Tom Riddle has never once desired legitimate companionship, but as he watches the stag gallop away, he thinks, “This could really be the beginning of something.”

At Malfoy manor, three fireplaces crackle merrily in the formal living room. Tom drops a book onto the great oak table at the center of the space with a satisfying thwack.

 

Abraxas hesitantly picks up the book, silk sleeves of his robes brushing the cover before grasping it between elegant fingers. 

 

“Economics for the IB Diploma,” he reads out to the silent group of assembled gentlemen. “My Lord, what is this book? I do not recognize the author or the subject matter.”

 

On Tom’s face, Abraxas sees a truly terrifying expression of superiority. “This book is the key to improving the wizarding world. Forget blood politics, economics is how we can invest in our futures.”

 

Abraxas has concerns that his lord has succumbed to mania and the Malfoy lord has no interest in abandoning his philosophy of blood traitors and mudbloods. He has, however, earned a healthy fear of his lord’s cruciatus and in order to avoid pain, he decided to humor his leader. 

 

He flips to a random point in the book, manicured nails shining as the pages flash by. “Market failure occurs when the condition for the market is allocatively inefficient, resulting in either an under-allocation of resources or an over-allocation of resources.”

 

Goyle calls out, “What does that mean?”

 

Self importantly, Tom responds, “It all goes back to the concept of scarcity.” He has been attending Harry's evening economics classes religiously. This is all easy to him.

 

Abraxas turns to another page, heart beating fast. “Stagnation occurs within economies where total output is either declining, flat, or growing at a very limited pace. Persistent unemployment is characteristic of this condition. Stagnation results in flat job growth, no wage increases, and an absence of stock market booms or highs.”

 

Rowle asks, “What are stocks?”

 

Tom smiles mysteriously and says, “You’ll need to read that book to find out.”

 

Abraxas, being rather smart, guesses, “We’re stagnating, aren’t we?”

 

Tom sits on an ottoman with a silver mink fur throw blanket draped over the top. “Oh yes, indeed we are. The wizarding world is trapped in time and our new cause is to bring a legitimate financial system to this country.”

 

Abraxas eyes a topic about profit margins and sighs internally. He did like the goal of eradicating those lesser than him, but the promise of increased wealth and a growing world does appeal to him. As always, he thanks his instincts for promising fealty to his lord. 

 

“IB Economics it is,” he agrees. 

 

Tom’s satisfaction is almost a tangible thing. 

 

***

 

Tom is sitting next to Harry at the high table absent-mindedly eating as he meticulously absorbs information in his new biology textbook. He wonders if Harry will say anything about his new subject of study. He looks forward to discussing photosynthesis with Harry and considering how it affects a variety of magical plants. 

 

When Tom turns to observe Harry out of the corners of his eyes, he notices that Harry looks rather pale and uncomfortable. He keeps tugging at the collar of his cable-knit sweater and swearing under his breath. He pushes eggs around his plate and has not eaten even one bite.

 

Concerned, Tom closes his book and gives Harry his full attention.

 

“What’s wrong?”

 

Harry startles and his emerald gaze snaps to Tom. His eyes are 

so green. 

Like a lush forest where Tom could lose himself. 

 

Harry self-consciously scratches the back of his neck. “That obvious, huh?”

 

Tom retrieves a treacle tart and slides it onto Harry’s plate. He cuts the tart into a bite-sized piece and raises it to Harry’s lips. 

 

“That is not an answer,” he notes. 

 

Harry goes cross-eyed looking at the tart. “What are – what are you doing?”

 

Tom presses the tart piece insistently against Harry’s full lips. “If you insist on deflecting my questions, I insist on you eating. 

 

“Oh for the love of –” Harry begins, and grabs the fork right out of Tom’s hands to bite the tart himself. When he grabs the fork, his pinky and ring fingers brush over Tom’s and Tom feels warmth spread over him. Obligingly he lets his hand drop from the utensil and watches as Harry swallows the first bite and then takes another. He closes his eyes and releases a small moan. “Oh, that is good.”

 

Tom watches in rapt attention and feels intensely jealous of the fork as Harry closes his lips around it. 

 

Harry continues eating, clearly thinking that Tom will drop his questioning.

 

Tom will not.

 

Once Harry has finished the tart, Tom asks again, “Why are you… nervous?”

 

Harry sighs. “You’re like, impossible to get off track. You know that, right? Obsessive.”

 

“That’s me,” Tom says with a winning smile. “I will never give this up so you may as well tell me now.”

 

Harry sighs again and studies his plate. “So you know how my last name is ‘Potter’?”

 

Tom says, “Indeed, I do.”

 

“And, well, James Potter thinks I look an awful lot like him so he told his family about me, and now they want to meet me in case we’re, well, related.”

 

Tom absorbs that. He barely paid any attention to the Potter boy in Gryffindor. He's well enough at defense, rowdy, just another pureblood ponce. Dressed in distressed jeans and combat boots, Harry has hardly ever looked like a pureblood wizard. Furthermore, Tom is fairly sure that Harry was raised by muggles. The Potters are renowned for taking children seriously and Tom cannot believe Harry would have ever been abandoned by such a prominent wizarding family. 




“Hogwash,” Tom says, “Weren’t you raised by muggles?”

 

“I was,” Harry confirms. Tom’s natural skill as a legimillens allows him to know this is the truth. “But, well, I have wondered if…”

 

“If?” Tom prompts.

 

“The resemblance and our shared last names would cause…questions.”

 

Tom asks, “Would you want to be a Potter?”

 

Harry tugs at a stand of his hair. “I don’t know,” he whispers, “I’m not sure wanting has anything to do with it. It’s just something I am.”

 

Tom catches on to that phrase. “You think you’re a Potter? From the wizarding world?”

 

Harry’s breath catches. “I – I don’t know.”

 

Tom's eyes narrow. 

 

That was a 

lie.


 

***

 

The Potter family requests Harry meets them in their home, so Harry takes the floo from his office. He yells out, “Potter Manor,” and then is whisked away.

 

He stumbles out of the fireplace, soot-covered, into a stately home with high ceilings and cream-colored rugs. He needs to take a moment to catch himself and dust his knees before straightening.






The Potters, Harry’s grandparents, and great-uncles, and even James, his father that he’s been getting to know, are all assembled in proper Wizarding robes in front of him. 

 

Harry regrets his choice of outfit very dearly and wishes he’d sucked it up and put on some robes. 

 

“Well,” a woman says in a no-nonsense sort of voice, “He certainly has the looks and floo clumsiness of a Potter.”

 

A man who looks like an older version of both Harry and James coughs slightly to hide a laugh. “Quite right, Euphemia, quite right.”

 

“Professor,” James says with a blinding grin, “Come on, I’ll show you to the table. Mum and Aunt Dorea prepared a bunch of tea accompaniments.”

 

Harry is led to a large dining room that has one glass wall facing a garden. The garden is filled with flowers in full bloom, autumn trees with orange, pink, and golden leaves, and a red bridge over a large pond reflecting all the colors like a mirror. A single swan swims leisurely and creates ripples in the crystal water. 

 

Harry takes a seat next to James and startles as a few scones march to his plate and begin buttering themselves. 

 

He never has used magic like this. He watches in rapt attention as the cups fill on their own with tea and use morse code to ask him how much sugar and cream he would like. He feels a lump in his throat as he wonders if he’d have been taught these household charms growing up if his parents or grandparents had lived to be there in his childhood. 

 

Once Harry has taken his first sip of tea, everyone goes about introducing themselves. Charlus and Dorea Potter look very wealthy indeed and their son, Henry, looks a bit smug but not terribly unpleasant. Harry notes that they are his great-aunt, great-uncle, and a sort of cousin but one generation removed. It’s odd to think of it like that when Harry in this universe is much older than James and only a bit younger than Henry. Fleamont and Euphemia introduce themselves next and Harry cannot stop looking in absolute wonder at the both of them, memorizing the faces of his grandparents. 

 

James introduces himself with a flourish and says, “But you knew me already.”

 

Harry chuckles obligingly and says, “I do. A great student even if you seem allergic to homework.”

 

“Hey! I just skive off geography and maths. I’m 

great 

at econ and literature.” 

 

Harry almost retorts but Dorea raises her hand and Harry pauses. 

 

“As pleasant as this is, and it 

is 

pleasant, we did invite you here for a reason, Mr. Harry 

Potter.”


 

Everyone suddenly seems focused. 

 

“I heard you were raised by muggles,” Euphemia mentions. 

 

“I was,” Harry says. “Until I was 17.”

 

“And then you lived on your own?” She asks.

 

Harry thinks of the days of living with Ginny and the two of them breaking up, and getting back together, and then spending one idyllic summer with each other and realizing after unsatisfying sex they felt like siblings and loved each other just not like… that. 

 

They kept living together, and Harry dated some guys and Ginny dated some girls, and Ron and Hermione applauded them both. 

 

“I lived with my best friends until I got this job.”

 

“I see,” Dorea comments. “Were they wizards?”

 

“They were. Best ones I’ve ever met.”

 

“Hm,” Charlus says. 

 

“He certainly seems like a Potter,” Fleamont says.

 

“But we’d certainly never abandon one of ours,” Henry says. “So if he is a Potter, how did he end up in the muggle world?”

 

“Enough chitter-chatter, we can ask those questions after we confirm whether or not he is one of us.”

 

James leans over and whispers, “Sorry about them talking to you like you’re not there.”

 

“We’ll do a simple direct descendant spell first,” Dorea decides. “The light will be blue and it will turn gold if you are the direct descendant of the caster. If you are not the direct descendant of any of the Potters here, we can get more creative and test out familial relations. Is this something you consent to?”





Harry feels out of his body. He supposes such a spell would glow for Fleamont and Euphemia unless his being in this alternate universe marks him as not being their grandchild. He has no idea what will happen and he doesn’t know if getting to be with all the family he saw in the mirror back when he was eleven and lonely is a good or bad idea. 

 

He certainly wants them. He has always wanted this family.

 

Maybe that’s why he nods even though he thinks it is a bad idea.

 

Charlus casts the spell first and the light remains blue.

 

Dorea purses her lips. “Fleamont?”

 

Fleamont casts the spell and as soon as the words pass his lips, Harry is enveloped in a golden light. 

 

Euphemia gasps and as soon as the spell ends immediately casts it herself. Harry is again lit up in a golden halo.

 

Fleamont says, dryly, “Did you think I was unfaithful?”

 

Euphemia seems incredibly overcome with emotion and she manages a watery, “Love potions and memory charms do exist, dearest.”

 

She and Fleamont stare at Harry with wide eyes and Dorea shakes herself. Charlus says, “How is this possible?”

 

Euphemia apparates directly to Harry’s side without bothering to stand up from her chair and immediately throws her arms around him.






“Oh my son, I do not how I forgot you, but I am so sorry.” She begins weeping softly into his shoulder. 

 

James’ eyes bug out of his head. 

 

Fleamont comes over more slowly, and rests his hand on Harry’s head. “I am sorry to have failed you, but we will make it up to you. Oh, my son.”

 

Harry feels he ought to correct them but he has no idea how to explain that he is actually their grandchild when he is older than James. 

 

Harry is brought into a cozy family room where his grandparents and father crowd around, Euphemia clutching at his arm and mentioning that her grandfather had green eyes. 

 

Dorea looks serious. “We have to assume then that there was foul play. Someone took the child from the Potters and placed him with muggles. For what reason, I cannot surmise.”

 

Fleamont says, gruffly, “Do you know who took you?”

 

Harry says, “I don’t. I’m sorry.”

 

Euphemia makes a wounded noise. “You have nothing to be sorry for, do you hear me? Nothing. Oh, to think if James hadn’t said anything I might never have found you…”

 

Dorea and Euphemia both look murderous and Fleamont and James seem overjoyed to have Harry join their family. 




“A long-lost big brother!” James crows. “Oh, Sirius will LOVE this. You’ll have to stay with us in the summer, of course. Sirius was so butthurt he couldn’t leave campus today because he’s practically one of us now but good old Dumbles didn't let him get the day, but you’ll see plenty of him for holidays.”

 

Harry coughs. “Well, I do have my own place and I’m already forty…”

 

“I am 69  and I think you must stay with us,” Fleamont says. “Keep your place but stay with us anyway.”

 

Euphemia says, “I’m a bit older than that, and I know we are strangers, but I am your mother and it would so much to me if I got the chance to know you better.”

 

“I suppose I can spend some of the summer…” Harry is cut off when Euphemia throws her arms around him and Fleamont starts crying. 

 

Harry is carted off to Gringott’s where the goblins confirm Harry is indeed the direct descendant of both Euphemia and Fleamont. They eye him a bit warily. 

 

Euphemia and Fleamont name Harry heir in addition to James, tell him they’re so proud of him, that they’ll write him every week, that they 

love him so much, 

and then James and Harry return to Hogwarts in the late evening. 

 

Harry is about to make it up to his rooms when Tom comes out of nowhere and grabs his wrist.

 

Harry looks into Tom’s eyes and sees they are burning with intensity. 

 

“And? Are you a Potter?”

 

Harry’s mind is a bit in disarray. He will spend the summer with his godfather, father, and grandparents. They all love him. Just one day after meeting him and they love him. All this family he never had a chance to meet took one look at him stumbling out of a fireplace and called him their own. He’s never had family like this before. The Weasleys loved him but he was never one of them all the way down, he never had the red hair or the freckles.

 

But these Potters, they have his black hair and face shape and they’re like him and they love him. 

 

“Yes,” he says faintly. “James is calling me his brother.”

 

“His 

brother? 

How on earth did you end up in the muggle world?”

 

“They think I was kidnapped or something. And then their memories were wiped.” Even though Harry knows this is all a lie, it does seem to be a better story than, ‘oh yeah, Tom.  I’m actually from the future in another universe and I came over here to keep you from murdering everyone I love.’

 

Tom does something entirely unexpected and pulls Harry into a hug. He’s strong and smells like pine, nettle, and something expensive. All of Harry’s senses go haywire and he tries to push against Tom but somehow only burrows closer. 

 

“That must have been hard. To have realized you had family all this time but didn’t even know you were alive.”

 

Harry’s mind thinks, a bit hysterically, 

is tom showing actual empathy right now? 

He also thinks, it is hard. It's hard to see the different life I could have had if they survived.

 

“...Yeah.”

 

Tom pulls back and gives Harry a once-over. “Psychology textbooks are so helpful.”

 

Harry realizes that Tom must have been testing out something he got from the psychology book but he cannot help but feel like Tom reading anything from muggles is a huge win. 

 

“How’s biology going?”





Triumphantly, Tom says, “I learned about meiosis.”

 

Harry nods. “Cell division is one of my favorites.”

 

Tom walks Harry to his rooms, and they talk about anaphase the whole way there.

 

***

 

Tom comes to Harry’s next seventh-year economics class and notices how James saunters in and calls out, “Heya, Professor Brother.”

 

Harry smiles and responds, “Little Potter, please take a seat.”

 

Sirius Black falls onto his desk laughing hysterically. “Oh dear lord, Prongs, I will from now on only ever refer to you as ‘Little Potter.’”

 

James looks playfully betrayed and Harry grins wickedly. “Everyone, welcome welcome. Today we are going to talk about exchange rates.”

Tom grins at her and slides her the IB economics book across the table. “You’ll find that it can. Please, review the chapters on money theory and supply.”
 
She squints at him some more. She nods, once. “I appreciate someone who understands the value of learning. I will go and review this book and make my choice after.”
 
Tom leans back in his chair. “Come back at your convenience. We look forward to your patronage.”
 
Griselda Marchbanks levels him with an unimpressed stare. “You are awfully cocky, aren’t you?”
 
Tom winks. “It’s easy to be arrogant when you’re right.”
 
More to herself than to Tom, Marchbanks mutters, “You were cocky when you took your NEWTS too, and you aced every single one of them.” More audibly she says, “Thank you for your time,” before exiting the office. 
 
***
 
Harry gets permission to begin teaching muggle studies to first-year students. He writes a petition to the ministry to make muggle studies a mandatory course because it is important. He gets rejected, but that’s alright. Life is all about the  trying.  
***
 
Most prospective clients are not nearly as discerning as Griselda Marchbanks. Tom enjoys a quick meeting with newly married Pandora Lovegood. She is a wisp of a thing, but her power is obvious as her desire for money.
 
She begins the meeting by saying, “Please explain me to this concept of a ‘loan.’
 
Tom replies, “In essence, Four House Banks will provide you with a sum of money with the expectation that over time, you will pay us back for that money plus some additional fees.”
 
Pandora says, “In Gringotts, the amount of money I can withdraw must be less than or equal to the amount I already have in my vault. But you’re saying I don’t need to have money to use money?”
 
Tom gives her his most comforting smile. “To be sure miss Lovegood, this money is not given out willy-nilly. The underwriting team will do a basic review of your assets and liabilities in order to determine the risk of your defaulting, but to answer your question, yes. We will give you money and you certainly do need to already possess the amount we will lend you.”
 
Lovegood adopts a dreamy expression. “And then I pay you back once I use that money you give me to make more money?”
Tom adds, “Or get more money from your profession, but essentially yes. That is truly the whole point of this system.  And we do charge a slight fee for the privilege of getting a loan, but it is worth it for most people.”
 
Lovegood seems to bring herself down to earth. “What happens if I can’t pay?”
 
Matter of factly, Tom responds, “We will seize all your monetary assets until the debt is settled. In your case, it would be quite everything, I'm afraid.”
 
Lovegood extends her hand to shake Tom’s hand. With a manic gleam in her eye, she says, “Sounds like a good deal. I was worried you would take my magic or something. Count me in.”
 
***
 
Six months after the bank is founded, Griselda Marchbanks opens an account. She brings with her several old and wealthy clients. Four House Banks is delivered a note from Gringotts asking them to close. They do not.
 
***
 
Harry writes another note asking to make muggle studies required curriculum. He is shot down again, but more politely.
 
***
 
Three years after the bank is opened, an impoverished man who has never had much to himself walks into the bank. His red hair is lanky and he just wants a better life for his five sons. He hates his low-paying job at the ministry where everyone stares down their noses at him and laughs at his tattered robes and his dreams of doing something with muggle technology.
 
When he comes in for his meeting, he shrinks from the fanciness and efficiency of Four House Banks’ flagship office’s interior. He is given a water bottle from an employee wearing a blazer that must cost more than four times Arthur’s salary.
 
“Arthur Weasley?” The employee asks with a tilted head scanning a crisp file. “It says here that you are of special interest.”
 
Arthur gulps. “Special interest?”
 
“That’s a good thing, dear. Here, follow me.”
 
Arthur is led to a large lift that is far more friendly than the ones in the ministry and hums happily to him as it gently zooms around the building. 
 
Arthur is let out onto what seems to be the executive office on the top floor. The whole floor makes up this one office and Arthur stares in shock at the large windows, an interior garden, and the sound of a gently bubbling stream. 
 
“Over here,” a rich voice calls, and Arthur follows the sound to a sofa where Harry Potter himself is sitting.
 
Harry Potter is the muggle studies professor at Hogwarts but he is somewhat of a legend too, being one of the two founders of this very bank.
 
Arthur cannot understand why he would get to have a personal meeting with such a busy and important figure. 
 
“Come, sit, sit,” Harry says, eyes much too fond for looking at a stranger.
 
Arthur sits, gingerly, embarrassed of his shabby clothes. “Well then, hello. I am Arthur. Weasley! Arthur Weasley, that is.”
 
Harry laughs in a way that somehow sounds expensive and comforting all at once. “I am very much aware.”
 
Arthur flushes. “Right. Right then.”
 
Harry's bright green eyes are soft. “So the reason you are here today?”
 
Arthur fiddles with a loose thread. “I want to borrow money. I mean I’m sure everyone does. And I looked at your requirements for the loan of the size I want and I don’t meet them, but I thought maybe I could make a case for why maybe we could work something out?”
 
Harry nods once, encouragingly. “Yes, after reviewing your financial information, I admit you wouldn’t normally qualify for much of anything here. That being said, I like you, Arthur. I want you to tell me what you would do with the money.”
 
Arthur takes a deep breath. “Muggles make the most amazing products. They innovate all the time, from their pellyphones to their toast boxes. And I think I’m close to learning how to make all the things muggles make that magic destroys magic proof or really, well, I’ve been working on how to remake some muggle inventions but make them run on magic instead of elictrickacy and the people at the ministry, well, they think I’m crazy and I’m going to make cursed items but I think it will change the world, really I do, and the only one I’ve figured out so far is this thing called a television but this could be somehting, it really could, and that’s why I thought I would come to you. To make it happen.”
 
Harry nods when Arthur finishes his speech. Arthur fiddles some more. He’s been impolite. Belatedly he adds, “Sir. That’s why I came to you  Sir.”  
 
Harry lays a hand on Arthur’s shoulder. It’s thin and awfully delicate for this giant of a man who is changing the world. “Mr. Weasley,” he says and there’s something in his eyes that is emotional and looks almost like grieving love, “I believe in you.”
 
“What?” Arthur asks, mouth falling open.
 
“I believe in you,” Harry repeats with a warm voice. Arthur’s not sure he’s ever heard that before. Certainly not from anyone that mattered, except maybe his wife.
 
Harry ends up giving him the money for free. All he asks is that Arthur open an account when the business takes off. 
 
“I will sir, I cannot thank you enough,” he says, vigorously shaking Harry’s hand in complete shock.
 
When Arthur calls the lift, he almost thinks he hears, “No. It’s me who can never thank you enough.”
 
Harry is kind enough to put Arthur in touch with a muggle-born consultant, a man named Ted Tonks, and the two of them work together to make the first magic-powered television. They release their first magical television (called MTV for short) in early 1980, a day after Ron is born. The MTVs are purchased only by niche consumers, and the Weasleys live as a very solidly middle-class family.
A few months after, Harry Potter and Tom Riddle gush about how much they love watching movies when they’re cuddled up together in the winter during an interview with the Daily Prophet.
 
After that, the business explodes and Ted and Arthur struggle to learn how to scale their business amidst insanely increased demand.
 
One of Arthur’s friends slides him a book titled,  Economics for the IB Diploma.  
 
“My daughter made me read that,” Davey Gudgeon says. “There’s a chapter on economies of scale. That’s a good place to start.”
 
Arthur reads the whole book cover to cover. Then he buys several more muggle books teaching him how to scale and run a business.
 
(As magical televisions catch on, seeds are planted that will one day grow into a wizarding Hollywood. But that’s decades away.)
 
By the time Ginny Weasley is born in 1982, the Weasley family is on its way to becoming blessedly happy and very comfortable. It's still quite intense then, as they are doing their absolute best to meet demand and not quite getting there. They will, but that's a few years away. Harry comes to visit Molly and Arthur after the birth as he has somehow become a family friend and often attends Sunday brunches. 
 
Arthur will never forget having someone believe in him. Harry, for his part, seems to somehow share the sentiment even though he has no reason to. 
 
Arthur wrings his hands on this beautiful Sunday while Molly is holding their newborn. “Harry,” he begins, “Would you like to, well, would you like to be Ron’s godfather?” The toddler glances at Harry shyly from behind his father's legs.
 
Harry blinks once, absolutely stunned. His eyes then fill up with what looks shockingly like tears. “I would be – honored.” He swallows once before his face breaks out into the most brilliant smile Arthur has ever seen. He leans down so he and Ron are close to eye level. Ron gives him a tentative wave. 
 
“Hey there, Ron. I can just tell you and I will be the best of friends.”
 
***
 
The ministry writes Harry in 1981 informing him that his version of muggle studies is now part of the required Hogwarts curriculum for all seven years.
 
***
 
Tom spoons Harry in bed one night when they are both getting on in years and starting to learn what it means to have aching backs and creaking knees. “To think if I’d never met you, I’d be attempting to fight a war.”
 
Harry looks up at the needlessly lavish precious stone mosaic of the ocean on their ceiling, glittering sapphires glinting orange from the dying embers in their marble fireplace. 
 
“You like this more?”
 
“I used to dream of being rich when I was young. Money is power darling, and power is all I have ever craved. We are wealthier than the Malfoys ever were.”
 
Owning seven villas, six castles, and an ungodly collection of jewels was not what Harry had in mind when he introduced the wizarding world to economics, but he admits that even if he’s not nearly as materialistic as Tom, nothing beats sex on a secluded island with a private view of a distant erupting volcano. 
 
As a child raised in a cupboard, his life feels rather dreamlike, but Harry is coming to terms with it. It’s not like he’s hurting anyone by being rich and he and Tom donate plenty. More than anyone else in the wizarding world ever has. 
 
“Come here,” he whispers, and pulls Tom in for a kiss.
